newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algiers car bomb kills three, wounds 70 - hospital.
newsitem.headline: Algiers car bomb kills three, wounds 70 - hospital.

text.p: A car bomb exploded near a crowded cafe in central Algiers on Monday killing at least three people and wounding 70, Algerian hospital sources said.

"Three people died on the spot and 70 others who were injured were ferried here in Mustapha Bacha (hospital) but more than 40 slightly injured returned home after treatment," said a medical source speaking by telephone from the Algerian capital.
Many of those badly injured in the rush-hour car bombing were transferred to other hospitals, another medical source added. Among the injuries were broken bones and eyes hit by shrapnel.
Security forces, wielding assault rifles, sealed the scene of the explosion, which wrecked a cafe, shattered windows and damaged cars. Many residents believed the bomb caused more casualties.
"I saw much blood at the scene. I fear many people might have died," a witness said by telephone from Algiers after the explosion at 12.45 a.m. (1145 GMT)

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the blast. More than 1,400 civilians have died in bomb attacks by fundamentalist Moslem rebels in the past two years, according to a government human rights body.
Monday's car bomb ripped through the commercial Larbi Ben Mehidi's street at rush hour, destroying the cafe and badly seriously a pizzeria and a betting office, withnesses said.
"A young man hurriedly left a car he had just parked near Novelty cafe and a moment later the explosion hit the place," said one man, speaking from his office near the site of the blast.

Another witness said "trails of blood covered the pavement" and the cafe was wrecked. "There were many people in the place as employees left offices for lunch and a lot of passers-by were also there."
About 60,000 people, mostly Moslem militants and security forces members, have died since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election radical Islamists were set to win.
Monday's bomb came a day after Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia asserted the government had defeated the guerrillas and "terrorism is living its latest convulsive moment".

The deadliest bomb attack was in January, 1995, when a suicide bomber slammed a car into central Algiers's main police station, killing at least 42 people and wounded nearly 300. The Armed Islamic Group, most ruthless of Algeria's fundamentalist movements, claimed responsibility.
